abstract.t: This documents specifies an application of Backplane to a scenario involving authentication and identity information passing.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: While Backplane is a generic framework for message exchange between trusted applications in the context of a browser session, the Identity Scenario is a specific protocol that facilitates authentication and identity transactions between those applications.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Representation Of Identity Information
section.t: User identity information communicated between Backplane parties in this scenario is represented in Portable Contacts (PoCo) format with some restrictions and extensions.
PoCo data is presented in the JSON format.
Since the scenario deals with a single user (the one performing identity-related actions in the context of a concrete browsing session), PoCo response node MUST contain a single "entry" object.
The "entry" object MUST contain the "accounts" element with at least one item. Each of the account items represents an identity.

An identity is represented by "identityUrl" element, which can be either a plain URL of user identity, or normalized SGN identity URI constructed from domain/userid pair by putting these values together: sgn://<DOMAIN>/?ident=<USERID>. In the latter case SGN identity URI MUST be recognized by Google's SGNodeMapper.

section.title: Message Types
section.t: Below is a list of Backplane message types employed in this scenario.

section.title: identity/login
section.t: This message is transmitted whenever an application (e.g. an Identity Manager) on a Backplane channel authenticates a user against an identity provider (e.g. Twitter or Facebook). The only party that is allowed to post this message is the one that directly facilitated the authentication (login) process (e.g. an Identity Connector).

The payload of the 'identity/login' message is a JSON object which contains the following fields:
the URL of the page where the authentication took place a PoCo object listing the identities that the user has gained by authenticating

section.title: identity/logout
section.t: This message is transmitted whenever an application (e.g. an Identity Manager) on a Backplane channel logs the user out of an identity provider (e.g. Twitter or Facebook). The only party that is allowed to post this message is the one that directly facilitated the logout process (e.g. an Identity Connector).

The payload of the 'identity/logout' message is a JSON object which contains the following fields:
the URL of the page where the logout took place a PoCo object listing the identities that the user has dropped with the logout

section.title: session/ready
section.t: This message is transmitted whenever Echo platform successfully creates a session for the user (and optionally creates a user record if one did not exist before) using the payload information from the identity/login message mentioned above or when an users logs out.

The payload of the "session/ready" message is a JSON object which contains the following field:
a JSON object with user identity information stored in the session

section.t: As you can see, the record has data in PoCo format in a separate field with name "poco", and Echo platform specific information is transmitted in the field "echo". The "echo" field stores information about state of the user in the Echo platform â€“ the user's roles, markers, and an identity specific information in the "accounts" field. For example, the field "loggedIn" stores information about whether an user successfully logged with the specified identity or not. The "identityUrl" field stores normalized identity URL (recovered from SGN form to a profile URL or a plain URL for the OpenID identities).

section.title: Use Cases
section.t: The following use cases illustrate the process highlighting implementation details of the Echo service, but it is important to note that Echo is not in any way a 'special' party. Any other similar service can employ the Backplane Identity Scenario without a need to inform or modify other parties.

section.title: Interacting Parties
section.t:
The use cases mentioned below make use of the following interacting parties:
A customer, serving content off http://customer.com. An independent Backplane server (running CNAMEd to backplane.customer.com), serving the customer's bus.
Widgets on the customer's page:
Echo Stream Client (ESC) Identity Manager (IM) Login Status Widget (LSW)
Identity Connector idcon.com, acting as a server-side counterpart of the IM. Echo server components:
an API endpoint for Echo widgets on the customer's page (available behind echoapi.customer.com CNAME). an API endpoint for server-to-server communication (available as api.aboutecho.com). a bus consumer - a server component listening to all messages broadcast on the customer's bus.
Echo Submission Proxy

All the parties are configured to use the same Backplane bus "customer.com". The configuration includes merely stating the Backplane server address and bus identifier for widgets (operating in read-only mode). Parties that post data (e.g. the Identity Connector) or listen to the entire Backplane bus (e.g. the Echo bus consumer) also need to have a username/password set up with the Backplane server to perform secure HTTPS requests with basic HTTP authentication.

section.title: Identity Manager
section.t: Identity Manager (IM) is an Echo-specific widget that allows user to manage their identity. IM is not required to be a part of the workflow and is described here just to aid in understanding of the use cases.

Once the page loads, Identity Manager fetches a list of supported identity providers (e.g. Twitter, Facebook, Customer's Own Login System) from its per-domain configuration. Each item of the list contains:
Identity Provider's favicon. Identity Provider's name ("Twitter", "Facebook"). A URL of an Identity Connector that facilitates logins/logouts for the Identity Provider in this context (e.g. for this customer).
This way a customer may mix and match which Identity Connectors are used to deal with specific Identity Providers.

Identity Manager presents the Identity Provider list to the user for selection. Once the user chooses to authenticate against a certain provider, the Identity Manager opens the Identity Connector's URL in a popup passing it the Backplane channel id as a parameter.
This procedure is not detailed below in the use cases for the sake of brevity; it is referred to only as "the user initiates a login using IM".

section.title: Echo Submission Proxy
section.t: Echo servers don't accept insecure data submissions: all such requests have to be securely signed and originate from a server side. This prevents a widget from submitting data directly to Echo APIs (otherwise a secret would be exposed).

In order to circumvent such limitation Echo widgets use server counterparts which:
receive data from the widgets via an ad-hoc protocol; perform authorization checks to make sure that the current user is indeed allowed to submit the data; place the data on the Echo server in a secure manner.
These components are called "submission proxies" since they pass through data submission requests.
Echo Submission Proxy (ESP) is the submission proxy for Echo Stream Client.

section.title: Backplane Initialization
section.t:
All use cases below share the following initialization sequence, taking place at the very beginning:
Echo bus consumer connects to the Backplane bus (starts polling the Backplane server with GET requests to http://backplane.customer.com/v1/bus/customer.com). An end user loads a Backplane-enabled page at http://customer.com/pages/1. Once the page loads, Backplane library checks if there is a cookie named 'backplane-channel' set against customer.com. If the cookie is set, its value is parsed and the library gets information about a channel name associated with bus name customer.com. Otherwise the library generates a new channel name and records information about the channel name and bus name association in the cookie set against customer.com domain. Backplane library starts asynchronous polling of channel http://backplane.customer.com/v1/bus/customer.com/channel/<CHANNEL_NAME> with GET requests. ESC, IM and LSW all call Backplane library and register their callbacks. ESC makes a call to http://echoapi.customer.com/v1/users/whoami to learn the user's identity, passing the channel id as a parameter.

section.title: Use case 1: A brand-new user logs in

list.t: The initialization takes place.

Echo server behind echoapi.customer.com looks up if there is an active session object associated with the channel id. Since it's a brand new login, there isn't one so the Echo server replies to the request with "you are anonymous" response.
The user initiates a login using IM.
IM performs the login sequence communicating with idcon.com and using the channel id as a unique identifier of the session.
Once the login workflow is complete, idcon.com creates an 'identity/login' message and posts it to the Backplane channel (this is a secure server-to-server call).
Backplane library receives the 'identity/login' message and notifies all interested widgets (ESC, IM, LSW).
LSW trusts the message without verification and updates its display (now shows "Logged in as ...").'
Backplane library receives the 'session/ready' message with user account information and passes it to ESC (as part of subscribers notification process).
ESC updates visual representation of the echo stream using new information about the user.

section.title: Use case 2: A logged-in user loads the page

list.t: The initialization takes place. Since the user is logged in, the Backplane channel id is passed along to the 'whoami' API endpoint of Echo.
Echo server looks up a session associated with the channel id.
If the session still exists, the user account information is passed back to ESC.

section.title: Use case 3: A logged-in user logs out

list.t: The initialization takes place. Since the user is logged in, the Backplane channel id is passed along to the 'whoami' API endpoint of Echo.
Echo server looks up a session associated with the channel id.
If the session still exists, the user account information is passed back to ESC.
The user initiates a logout using IM.
IM performs the logout sequence communicating with idcon.com and using the channel id as a unique identifier of the session.
Once the logout workflow is complete, idcon.com creates an 'identity/logout' message and posts it to the Backplane channel (this is a secure server-to-server call).
Backplane library receives the 'identity/logout' message and notifies all interested widgets (ESC, IM, LSW).
LSW trusts the message without verification and updates its display.
ESC sends another request to http://echoapi.customer.com/v1/users/whoami (passing the channel id along).
Echo server looks up the session object by the channel id and communicates the user account information to ESC using a proprietary protocol.

section.title: Use case 4: A third-party widget needs to learn the login status of the user after the fact
section.t: Backplane Identity Scenario is a stateless protocol. There is no way to retrieve the current state from Backplane. In order to do that a widget or client needs to keep track of Backplane events occuring on a channel. Another possibility is to use an API of a service which does that (for example, if a widget is certain that Echo is on the Backplane channel, the former can get user account information from the Echo server directly).

section.title: Use case 5: A logged-in user opens another copy of the same window
section.t: Since the Backplane channel name is stored in the cookie, opening a new window without closing the original one is no different from Use case 2.

section.title: Use case 6: A user logs in on a page where no Echo Stream Client is present
section.t: Since Echo uses Backplane channel id which is stored in a cookie, the only requirement is that the Backplane library executed on the page where login happens. This will ensure that Echo will later be able to look up its session object by the channel id (Echo bus consumer will catch the 'identity/login' message and set up the association).

section.title: Use case 7: A user leaves a 'like' or reply

list.t: The initialization takes place. The channel name is either retrieved from the cookie or generated anew. ESC learns the user identity (if Echo server is aware of one).
Echo server looks up a session associated with the channel id.
If the session still exists, the user account information is passed back to ESC.
The user clicks 'like' button or submits a comment/reply.
ESC sends the data (using an ad-hoc protocol) to ESP running on esp.customer.com. Channel ID value is passed along.

ESP makes a (server-to-server) request to Echo servers to check if the Backplane channel ID received from ESC is associated with an active session on the Echo side. If no Backplane channel was received, ESP checks if anonymous posting/liking is allowed.
ESP then makes a decision (based on Echo server's response and established policy) if it is okay to submit the data.
ESP either submits the data and returns an acknowledgment to ESC or discards the data and returns error.
